questions.text: Which of the following functions are likely to be impaired in patients with peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Peripheral neuropathies can impair sensory, motor, or autonomic function, either singly or in combination.

Peripheral nerves are composed of sensory, motor, and autonomic elements.

Peripheral neuropathies are classified into those that primarily affect the

  • Cell body - neuronopathy or ganglionopathy
  • Myelin - myelinopathy
  • Axon - axonopathy

questions.text:
Disorders of autonomic function should be considered in patients with:
  1. Unexplained orthostatic hypotension
  2. Dysuria 
  3. Hyperhidrosis
  4. Urinary incontinence
  5. Dementia
questions.solution:
Disorders of autonomic function (dysautonomia) is usually considered in patients with:

  • Unexplained orthostatic hypotension (OH)
  • Syncope
  • Sleep dysfunction
  • Altered sweating (hyperhidrosis or hypohidrosis)
  • Impotence
  • Constipation or other GI symptoms like bloating, nausea, vomiting of old food, diarrhea.
  • Bladder disorders such as urinary frequency, hesitancy, or incontinence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman complains of numbness of her hands, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability. She is a vegetarian. She looks very pale and her peripheral smear reveals macrocytic hypochromic anemia. If untreated, she is at risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia and a vegetarian diet is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. This typically leads to large fiber neuropathy which presents with loss of proprioception and vibration.

Smaller-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. Hence, small fiber neuropathies present as temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.

Related Pearl: Nerve Fiber Types And Sensory Neuropathies

Depending on the nerve fibers involved (Large or Small), the sensory neuropathies are classified as follows:

A. Small fiber (Painful neuropathies: dissociated sensory loss)

  • Lepromatous leprosy
  • Amyloidosis
  • Diabetic small fiber neuropathy
  • HIV and antiretroviral therapy neuropathy

B. Large fiber (Ataxic neuropathies)

  • Sjogren’s syndrome
  • Vitamin B12 neuropathy
  • Pyridoxine toxicity
  • Cisplatin neuropathy

C. Mixed (small & large fiber) (Global sensory loss)

  • Diabetic sensory neuropathy
  • Hereditary sensory neuropathies
  • Carcinomatous sensory neuropathy

questions.text: Small fiber neuropathies can be seen in patients with all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
Sjogren’s syndrome does not cause small fiber neuropathy. It causes preferential large fiber sensory neuropathy.

 

Related Pearl: Nerve Fiber Types And Sensory Neuropathies

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with weakness of both the lower limbs. On examination, there is a sensory loss in the lower limbs and both the proximal and distal leg muscles have reduced power. This presentation is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests symmetric proximal and distal weakness with sensory loss. This pattern is characteristic of acquired immune demyelinating polyneuropathies.

It consists of:

  • Acute form - Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy [AIDP] also known as Guillain-Barré syndrome [GBS]
  • Chronic form - Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy [CIDP]

Option B: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a multiple degenerative motor neuron disease. It leads to muscle weakness and disability in the absence of sensory symptoms and signs.

Option C: Mononeuropathy multiplex refers to multiple compressive mononeuropathies. It presents as asymmetric subacute or acute sensory and motor symptoms and signs.

Option D: Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus presents with asymmetric weakness.

Related Pearl: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)
  • Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cancer (paraneoplastic)
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)
  • Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents
  • Vitamin B6 toxicity
  • Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 
  • Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy
  • Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus
  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: A patient presented with peripheral neuropathy with asymmetric distal weakness without sensory loss. The differential diagnosis for this condition would include all except:
questions.solution:
Hereditary motor neuropathy does not present with asymmetric distal weakness without sensory loss. It presents with symmetric distal weakness without sensory loss.

Related Pearl: Peripheral Neuropathies Without Sensory Loss

With Symmetrical Weakness

  • Spinal muscular atrophy
  • Hereditary motor neuropathy (“distal” spinal muscular atrophy) or atypical Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT)

With Asymmetrical weakness  

  • Motor neuron disease
  • Progressive muscular atrophy
  • Juvenile monomelic amyotrophy (Hirayama’s  disease)
  • Multifocal motor neuropathy
  • Multifocal acquired motor axonopathy

questions.text: What is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy.

Other examples of rare hereditary neuropathies are Friedreich’s ataxia, familial amyloid polyneuropathy and Tangier disease.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with autonomic neuropathies, except:
questions.solution:
In hyperthyroidism, excessive thyroxine causes sympathetic autonomic overactivity, not neuropathy. 

Hypothyroidism can be associated with peripheral neuropathy, most typically carpal tunnel syndrome. Treatment is the correction of hypothyroidism.

Related Pearl: Neuropathies associated with prominent autonomic dysfunction

  • Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy
  • Amyloidosis (familial and acquired)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Idiopathic pandysautonomia (may be a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome)
  • Porphyria
  • HIV-related autonomic neuropathy
  • Vincristine and other chemotherapeutic agents

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of insomnia due to her feet becoming very hot and painful at night. On examination, she has multiple superficial foot ulcers, and she is unable to feel light touch and crude touch. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of burning feet syndrome, seen in HSAN 1. 

There are five types of hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSAN I–V), of which the most important are HSAN I and HSAN III.

HSAN I has an autosomal dominant inheritance. It presents in adolescence or adulthood as a distal small-fiber neuropathy. It causes burning feet syndrome in which patients present with:

  • Burning sensation of feet, especially at night
  • Sensory loss
  • Foot ulcers.

Option B: Dejerine Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome usually occurs after a stroke. The patient experiences burning pain over affected areas of the body.

Option C: HSAN III or Riley Day syndrome presents in childhood. It presents with labile BP, decreased tearing, hyperhidrosis, reduced sensitivity to pain, and areflexia.

Option D: Charcot Marie Tooth disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. It is a hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) which presents with motor weakness and skeletal deformities.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of neuropathy seen in diabetes?

choices.text: Distal Symmetric Sensory and Sensorimotor Polyneuropathy

questions.solution:
Distal symmetric sensory and sensorimotor polyneuropathy (DSPN) is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy and is seen in approximately one-third of patients with DM.

Other neuropathies seen in diabetes mellitus are:

  • The most common mononeuropathies are median neuropathy at the wrist and ulnar neuropathy at the elbow
  • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy is typically seen in combination with DSPN
  • Cranial neuropathy (third nerve palsy is the most common) and diabetic neuropathic cachexia

The Michigan diabetic neuropathy score is a screening tool used to assess diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed as a first-line drug for a patient with painful diabetic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

  • First-line: 
    • Lidoderm 5% patch
    • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
    • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
    • Duloxetine
  • Second-line: 
    • Carbamazepine
    • Phenytoin
    • Venlafaxine
    • Tramadol
  • Third-line:
    • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: Sensorimotor neuropathy may be caused by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Lead poisoning does not cause sensorimotor neuropathy. It causes symptoms and signs of primarily motor neuropathy. The most common presentation of lead poisoning is encephalopathy.

The sensation is generally preserved but the autonomic nervous system can be affected in lead poisoning.

Related Pearl: Conditions causing sensorimotor neuropathy

Conditions causing sensorimotor neuropathy 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Uremia
  • Porphyria
  • Cryoglobulinemia
  • Drugs (Amiodarone, Isoniazid, Metronidazole)
  • Toxins (Arsenic, Diphtheria toxin, Organophosphates)

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins will you prescribe for a patient on antitubercular therapy?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid (INH), which is a first-line anti-tuberculosis drug, inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase, resulting in pyridoxine deficiency and neuropathy. Prophylactic administration of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) 10 mg/day can prevent neuropathy from developing. 

10 mg daily suffices for prophylaxis but patients with evidence of vitamin B6 deficiency may require up to 50 mg daily.

Current WHO guidelines recommend routine substitution of pyridoxine to patients who are at risk of peripheral neuropathy, e.g., malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetics, HIV.

However, pyridoxine excess (acute intoxication or long-term use of large doses) is also found to cause peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: During a regular health checkup, you notice the following nail finding in a 64-year-old man. He lives near a smelting industry on the banks of a river. Which of the following conditions can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows Mee’s lines, transverse white striae of the fingernails. This along with history is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning probably due to a contaminated water source. Arsenic poisoning causes toxic sensorimotor polyneuropathy.

The neuropathy manifests 5–10 days after ingestion of arsenic and progresses for several weeks, mimicking Guillain–Barre's Syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

The given image showing thickening of tissues in the temporal and orbital regions with coarse overlying skin suggests a diagnosis of plexiform neurofibroma.

Plexiform neurofibroma represents an uncommon variant (30%) of neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1). Plexiform neurofibromas are usually evident at birth and result from a diffuse thickening of nerve trunks and surrounding tissues that are usually located in the orbital or temporal region of the face. The skin overlying it may be coarse and associated with hyperpigmentation.

Plexiform neurofibromas may produce an overgrowth of an extremity and a deformity of the corresponding bone.

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules >5mm in prepubertal and >15mm in postpubertal
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris lisch nodules
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones with or without pseudoarthrosis.
  • Optic gliomas
  • A first-degree relative with NF-1
